body:
### Describe your issue

Web assembly is increasingly well supported in Python, and may end up being increasingly important.

My impression is that Cython extensions (mostly) run fine on web-assembly, at least within the limits of the platform (no threads?). We should possibly test this.

I've never used web-assembly personally so don't really know where to start even running it in browser. And I definitely don't know how you'd run it on a CI. But if anyone did know and had an interest in setting it up then I think it'd be worthwhile to test at least one Python version with it.

comment_data.body:
Yes we're very happy to help if you want to add wasm32-emscripten checks (ie Pyodide support) to ci. So far we have had good luck with cython just working. The most common problem we run into is people including cythonized sources in their sdists which makes it hard to update to new python versions packages that would otherwise be forwards compatible.

Something easy to improve wasm support is to always compile with 
`-Werror=implicit-function-declaration -Werror=mismatched-parameter-types -Werror=return-type` since those warnings will catch most of the problems specific to wasm.

If you have end to end tests that you are building and testing against a many linux target it shouldn't be too much trouble to add Pyodide as well.

Of course you say wasm here and there's also the wasm32-wasi targets. There's a lot more in common than different between wasm32-emscripten and wasm32-wasi so if you support either you're a long way towards supporting both. @brettcannon and @dicej are the contacts I know for wasi.

Hi @gabrielfougeron and @da-woods, thanks!

What I have to add probably isn't useful beyond what @hoodmane has mentioned, but one of the limits that WebAssembly hits in the browser with Pyodide is the size of the usable memory and the binary size of Cython-based extension modules is also a concern towards bandwidth usage, in cases where caching is inefficient. So I think approaches in the line of #6531 would also be incredibly useful.

Thanks for the comments all.

> So far we have had good luck with cython just working.

That's good to know. I don't think we've had any wasm issues reported, and it's nice to know that that's for good reasons.

> Something easy to improve wasm support is to always compile with
> `-Werror=implicit-function-declaration -Werror=mismatched-parameter-types -Werror=return-type` since those warnings will  catch most of the problems specific to wasm.

I'll see what happens if we add them to the tests generally.

> Of course you say wasm here and there's also the wasm32-wasi targets.

My feeling is that we don't need to be incredibly thorough (especially if things mostly just work).

> is the size of the usable memory and the binary size of Cython-based extension modules

We've tended to prioritize speed over size, and will probably continue to do so. And I'm not sure there's huge *easy* improvements to be made. But it'd definitely be nice to improve binary size in places.

------------------------------------------

> If you have end to end tests that you are building and testing against a many linux target it shouldn't be too much trouble to add Pyodide as well.

My impression is that most wasm/emscripted extensions are cross-compiled and only the extension runs in the browser? That's something that Cython supports fine but isn't how the tests are currently written - we tend to have a single process that runs Cython, calls the C compiler (as a subprocess) and then runs the tests of the compiled module. Am I right in thinking that this would have to change?

> My impression is that most wasm/emscripted extensions are cross-compiled and only the extension runs in the browser? That's something that Cython supports fine but isn't how the tests are currently written - we tend to have a single process that runs Cython, calls the C compiler (as a subprocess) and then runs the tests of the compiled module. Am I right in thinking that this would have to change?

The extension runs in the browser and also in JS/WASM runtimes like Node.js, and https://github.com/pyodide/pyodide-build provides a `pyodide venv` command that will set up a Pyodide virtual environment for you with a Python interpreter, where the platform name is "emscripten". While it offers a Pythonic interface, it is really a polyglot binary that runs Pyodide's cross-compiled rendition of CPython in Node.js. It is possible to install most packages, such as `pytest` and the like in it how you would install them in a more conventional Python virtual environment. However, spawning a subprocess with this interpreter would not work, however, as things are cross-compiled, you can run `pyodide build` to package the extension module(s) and load them in a WASM environment separately. I haven't looked into how Cython's test suite is organised or structured, but yes, you are right â€“ it might need to change ever so slightly.

@agriyakhetarpal I'm guessing you're talking about the ``.pyodide-xbuildenv-x.xx.x`` folder ?

 Do you have an example of a project that has a ``pytest`` test case suite that one can run in both native and in emscripten ? It's been a while since I had a look at the ``pyodide`` docs, maybe I'll find it there ... ?

> @agriyakhetarpal I'm guessing you're talking about the `.pyodide-xbuildenv-x.xx.x` folder ?

Ah, no, that's the cross-build environment folder. It is used when you want to cross-compile packages, as it provides the Pyodide runtime and necessary patched `sysconfig` data to do so. The Pyodide virtual environment (`pyodide venv`) offers a WASM Python interpreter similar to other virtual environments, which does not need the xbuildenv.

> Do you have an example of a project that has a `pytest` test case suite that one can run in both native and in emscripten ? It's been a while since I had a look at the `pyodide` docs, maybe I'll find it there ... ?

Yes, many Scientific Python packages have a `pytest`-based test suite that you can run in both natively and in Emscripten. NumPy, statsmodels, pandas, and many others, etc. would be some notable examples.

For instance, [statsmodels/statsmodels@`8600926`/statsmodels/tools/_test_runner.py](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/8600926f2f22e58779a667d82047a90318b20431/statsmodels/tools/_test_runner.py) runs `pytest.main()` with a bunch of user-defined arguments passed to it. However, a `subprocess`-based test runner would not work, of course.

I think it makes sense to expand more on this in the Pyodide docs on testing packages out-of-tree, a bit more than what we currently have.

title: Test webassembly
